title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body: Below you will find the takes of three different stakeholders on what role CCS technologies can play in combatting climate change. Read each perspective in detail and then answer the questions below.

title: 3 Perspectives on CCS
body: Below you will find the takes of three different stakeholders on what role CCS technologies can play in combatting climate change. Read each perspective in detail and then answer the questions below.

title: Carbon Capture and Storage
body:
First and foremost, what exactly is carbon capture and storage? The process typically involves three key steps: capture, transport, and storage. In the capture phase, specialised technologies trap CO2 emissions, preventing their release into the atmosphere. We must also navigate the logistical challenge of transporting these captured emissions to a storage site. Finally, the storage phase, where we carefully store the captured CO2, e.g. in geological formations deep underground. It's like locking away the carbon in a secure vault, ensuring it doesn't escape and contribute to the greenhouse effect.

In this video, we're exploring the what and why behind carbon capture and storage. So let`s get started!

title: New Block Title
body:
This first video discussed what CCS is and how it works. Knowing the basics is always the first step in understanding how these technologies can combat climate change and whether the technology can help us move towards a more sustainable future. As a next step, we have to examine each technology's possible advantages and disadvantages critically. 

On the advantageous side, carbon capture and storage (CCS) can significantly reduce carbon dioxide emissions, offering a tangible solution for industries across the spectrum. Its adaptability and versatility make it a valuable tool in our quest for sustainability, acting as a bridge technology during the transition to cleaner energy sources. However, the path to a carbon-neutral future has its challenges. The substantial financial investment required to implement CCS poses a notable drawback, potentially hindering widespread adoption. Additionally, the energy-intensive nature of the capture process and the impact on overall efficiency, coupled with the challenge of identifying suitable and secure geological formations for long-term storage, underscore the complexities and trade-offs inherent in this technology.

title: Questions
body: After reading the three different perspectives, please answer the following questions about the different stakeholders and their position towards CCS.

title: Sustainability-Related Technologies
body: This interactive graphic shows some sustainability-related technologies. These technologies are designed to reduce the negative impact of human activities on the planet and enhance our ability to meet the needs of present and future generations. Find out more about each of the fields of technologies where technologies are being developed or researched to address environmental, social, and economic challenges.

title: Explore the Interactive Graphic!
body: Explore the interactive graphic by looking at the different countries and regions and finding out how the emissions by sector change between other geographical areas. Answer the question below by finding the relevant data within the graphic.

title: The Linear (Industrial) Economy
body:
In the linear industrial economy, the process begins with the globalized industrialized production, involving the extraction and utilization of various resources such as water, energy, materials, and human resources like labor and skills. These elements are harnessed to manufacture goods ranging from infrastructure and buildings to equipment and durable products.

Once produced, the goods undergo the second stage: globalized distribution logistics. This phase encompasses the distribution of the manufactured items to points of sale, where commercialization occurs either at the factory gate or directly at the point of sale. The objects are then made available to consumers through various means, such as sales, leases, rentals, or as services, marking the completion of the linear process. This traditional model is marked by a one-way flow from resource extraction to disposal, contributing to issues of resource depletion and environmental impact.

title: Circular Economy vs. Circular Society
body: This table provides a concise overview of the differences between the two models across various dimensions. It offers insights into their temporal and spatial scales, sustainability considerations, perspectives on resource nexus, attitudes towards capitalism and decoupling, primary goals, and overarching narratives.

title: Linear Economy  Waste Management
body:
In a linear economy's waste management system, there is a notable concept known as the "liability border." This term refers to the point at which the responsibility for waste is shifted away from the producer and becomes someone else's problem. In the traditional linear model, once a product is sold and reaches the end of its life cycle, the producer often considers their responsibility fulfilled. The disposal and management of the resulting waste then become the concern of the consumer or local authorities.

This approach creates a disconnect between the production and disposal phases, leading to a lack of accountability for the environmental impact of the products. The linear economy's "take, make, dispose" model doesn't inherently incentivize producers to address the end-of-life impact of their goods. Consequently, the disposal of products becomes somebody else's problem, often burdening communities, waste management facilities, or the environment with the responsibility of dealing with the waste.
